body_content.explanation: abbreviation for large-scale integration: the process of putting thousands of transistors (= very small pieces of electronic equipment) on a single silicon chip (= a small piece of silicon that is used in computers, phones, etc.):
examples: Computers built after 1972 are often called "fourth generation" computers, based on LSI (Large Scale Integration) of circuits—typically 500 or more components on a chip.
LSI circuits approaching 10,000 transistors began to be produced around 1974.
